A. Pagaltzis wrote:
> I am still trying to get a grip on my thinking, but the point is
> that state means a different thing for the server than for the
> client. The client may keep implicit state that persists across
> requests, but the server may not. State on the server is always
> explicit, exposed via resources.

Both the server and the client will have state.

Connections do not have state. The server will not make any assumptions 
about the client's state based on previous operations. The client will 
not make any assumptions about the server's state based on previous 
operations (though checking that a previous known state is still valid 
may only require a cache look up - conceptually the client has still 
checked with the server).
